day1.title: Intention and Decluttering
day1.description: The Persian 'Khaneh-Tekani' (House Shaking) symbolizes casting out winter's darkness. Start small—clean just one drawer or shelf today.

day2.title: Donating Excess Items
day2.description: Separate items you haven't used in a year to donate; refreshing your home's energy begins with generosity.

day3.title: Clean Mirrors and Frames
day3.description: The mirror is a symbol of light and reflection in Persian culture. Polish all mirrors and family photo frames.

day4.title: Organize the Spice Cabinet
day4.description: Discard old spices and wipe down the jars. The scent of saffron and cardamom should fill your kitchen.

day5.title: Refresh Light Textiles
day5.description: Wash sheer curtains and cushion covers to bring a scent of freshness into every room.

day6.title: Clean Light Fixtures
day6.description: Lighting is key for the New Year. Clean the crystals and glass of your lamps so the house glows brightly.

day7.title: Plant Care
day7.description: Remove dry leaves and nourish the soil so your plants are ready to welcome the spring.

day8.title: Organize the Library
day8.description: Dust your books. Set aside a place of honor for the Divan of Hafez and the Quran (or your book of wisdom).

day9.title: Living Room Windows
day9.description: Clean the glass so 'Uncle Nowruz' doesn't stay outside! Sunlight should stream directly into the house.

day10.title: Plan the Samanoo
day10.description: Samanoo symbolizes blessing and power. If making it from scratch, soak the wheat today (it takes 3 days to sprout).

day11.title: Prepare the Samanoo
day11.description: Extract the juice from sprouted wheat and mix with flour. This traditional sweet pudding requires patience and stirring.

day12.title: Clean the Refrigerator
day12.description: Wipe down shelves and make room for the fruits and traditional sweets of the holiday season.

day13.title: Closet Organization (Part 1)
day13.description: Pack away heavy winter coats and sweaters in garment bags to clear space.

day14.title: Closet Organization (Part 2)
day14.description: Bring out your spring clothes, organize hangers, and add a fresh scent to the drawers.

day15.title: Deep Clean the Stove
day15.description: The stove represents the warmth of the home. Remove all grease stains using baking soda and vinegar.

day16.title: Refresh Table Linens
day16.description: Wash small tablecloths and runners to renew the look of your dining area.

day17.title: Clean the Entrance
day17.description: Organize the shoe rack and wipe down the front door; it’s the first thing your guests will see.

day18.title: Under the Furniture
day18.description: Vacuum the dust that has accumulated over the year under sofas and heavy furniture.

day19.title: Plant the Sabzeh
day19.description: If you want wheat sprouts, today is the ideal day to start soaking them so they are vibrant green by Nowruz.

day20.title: Small Appliances
day20.description: Clean the kettle, toaster, and microwave. Your daily kitchen tools should be spotless.

day21.title: Wash Floor Mats
day21.description: Wash the bathroom and entry mats or replace them if they are worn out.

day22.title: Polish Guest Dishes
day22.description: Clean and polish the crystal or silverware you save for special guests and the New Year dinner.

day23.title: Buy New Clothes
day23.description: Follow the tradition of 'wearing something new'—get a new garment, even if small, for the moment of transition.

day24.title: Spot Clean Walls
day24.description: Wipe away fingerprints and scuffs on the walls, especially around light switches.

day25.title: Prepare Senjed and Somaq
day25.description: Senjed (love) and Somaq (patience) are vital. Select the most beautiful ones for your table.

day26.title: Document Filing
day26.description: Discard old papers and organize important documents to start the year with order.

day27.title: Deep Clean Floors
day27.description: Mop and polish all floors in the house with a fresh-scented cleaner.

day28.title: Prepare Garlic and Vinegar
day28.description: Seer (health) and Serkeh (serenity) should be placed in decorative bowls for the Haft-Sin.

day29.title: Door Frames
day29.description: Dust the tops of door frames, a place that is often forgotten during regular cleaning.

day30.title: Select Red Apples
day30.description: The apple (Seeb) is a symbol of beauty. Look for perfect, shiny red apples for your display.

day31.title: Polish the Sink
day31.description: Deep clean the kitchen sink until it shines like a mirror for the final countdown.

day32.title: Get the Hyacinth
day32.description: The hyacinth flower (Sonbol) heralds spring. Choose one with your favorite color and scent.

day33.title: Prepare Shiny Coins
day33.description: Coins (Sekeh) symbolize prosperity. Clean a few bright coins to place on the table.

day34.title: The Haft-Sin Mirror
day34.description: Carefully polish the main mirror that will reflect your face at the moment of the New Year.

day35.title: Paint the Eggs
day35.description: Decorate eggs with bright colors—a perfect activity to enjoy with family or children.

day36.title: Water and Life
day36.description: Water represents purity. Prepare a bowl with fresh, clean water (and goldfish if desired) for your table.

day37.title: Set the Foundation
day37.description: Lay out your traditional fabrics (Termeh) and begin arranging the Haft-Sin bowls.

day38.title: Sweets and Nuts
day38.description: Arrange traditional sweets like chickpea cookies (Nokhodchi) on your serving platters.

day39.title: Final Haft-Sin Touches
day39.description: Place the Sabzeh, Samanoo, and books. Prepare the candles for the final moment.

day40.title: Happy Nowruz!
day40.description: Burn wild rue (Espand), dress in your new clothes, and celebrate the arrival of spring with loved ones.
